name: Santa Claus - a right jolly old elf, a dwarven mage or a gnomish illusionist?
author: Fist

posts.author: Theophilus Fist
posts.content:
While I wait for the star of the Christmas Eve dinner to finish cooking on the smoker, my thoughts have turned to Santa through the lens of NWN.

He looks like a stout, long bearded dwarf, but Clement Clarke Moore calls him a jolly old elf and Christmas magic definitely is illusory, which screams gnome.

I'm going to explore St. Nick first as a Wizard/COT/Harper, just because that combo is speaking to me, but I'm interested in the opinions of the ECB Guild.

1 - PVM - Santa isn't a gladiator

2 - Level 40

3 - Dwarf, Elf or Gnome

4 - Wizard is a favored class for elves and gnomes, but Santa could go heavy Bard, as well

5 - Santa is not much of a meleer, but would wield a one hander (his sack of toys is in the other), no shield as an arcane caster

6 - Dex based archer

7 - His cane would take the shape of a club, mace or staff

8 - Santa operates in a +5 environment

9 - Santa could be an Illusionist, a conjurer (summoning 8 bloodthirsty killer reindeer) or an evoker devastating the naughty with IGMS.

10 - I'm going to take him through a module, just to see - probably the Bastard of Kosigyan series.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
None of the above as far as I am concerned. He's always been quite human AFAIK.  The fact that he comes from the North Pole would probably indicate some Nordic or Germanic ancestry but since he is a myth I suppose anything goes.  The elves are his workers and I doubt they would enjoy a dwarf as their employer, not under typical AD&D mythology anyway. Gnomes are extremely clannish and mistrusting of those outside their race.  I don't see them as a match at all for agregarious sort.

Yeah, probably wizardly or even a druid, if you go divine.  His history suggests some god-like legacy and magicians (or at least some sort of diviner) are as close to gods as one can get.  He should use a staff I guess, a staff with one of those globes filled with snow mounted on top that he shakes when he yells "Ho ho ho!".  Leaves his other hand free to sling the bag over his shoulder.  He might need to re-light the fireplace after the concussion from his sudden visit settles down, so perhaps some fire-kindling spell like Burning Hands would be handy.

I don't think St. Nich is a trickster, nor bard (which is just a thief who happens to sing show tunes).  The occasional bag of coal is given as a warning of his own disappointment rather than a punishment.  Generally, he is a kind-hearted soul so either NG or LG works for me.  CG?  Probably not.  I don't see a chaotic Santa wearing a straight-jacket and being administered meds to get him back into social graces.  I've often wondered what Santa did after Christmas... his elves make all the gifts.  Who grooms the reindeer?  Elves would need ladder to reach them.  Just wondering... maybe spend some quality time with Mrs. Claus in Bermuda?  But then there is that bikini issue.   Hmmm.... needs more ruminating, I think.

I am not familiar with the series of modules you are referencing.  Does it use CEP? Is this new content?

Thanks for posting a topic in the holiday spirit, Mr. Fist.  It is the first (and possibly the last) of 2015.  Happy Holidays to you and those dear to you!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Saint Nick would be a Cleric, naturally. The Trickery domain and some Rogue levels would help him sneak into people homes to leave gifts.
For his alignment, his morality axis would definately be Good. I'm not sure where to place him on the ethics axis. Lawful because he judges whether children have been naughty or nice? Chaotic because he breaks into people's homes?
What about the other domain? Knowledge to help him divine children's niceness or naughtiness? Healing? Good? Or even Magic? Maybe another domain that I didn't think of?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Too bad you'll need an alignment manager or custom scripting of LC shifts by the designer to play this.  I am guessing your planned module furnishes exactly that. LC is the toughest shift to achieve without a manager of some sort judging from all the PWs and CC I've played, though not the BoK series.

Not sure what the value of extra music achieves with 24 per day already in the queue. I'd discard that completely, post the Curse version and be done with it.  Dump the Toughness so IKD appears within pre-epic.  WIS 11/INT 13 opens up Expertise to sub in the Toughness slot if IKD is not desirable.

Another shame is Dirge and Icestorms failing cast quite often in heavy equipment.  A high-level Bard would usually go Autostill to enable the full range of spell repertoire without robes.

Maybe shift the excess UMD and the token Lore allotment into Taunt to help vs. high Conc types (even with song boost, current Taunt level will fail most of the time and waste a combat round).  I'd have no compunction subbing ESkF:Perform for more smiting.  Screw the puny pre-epic skill boost. You've gotten other needs. Naturally, unless the module abounds in custom blueprints biased towards evil types (as your chosen venue may well contain), smite opportunities will be limited to undead, drow... the typical evil creature types.  With the epic skill boost you may actually be able to raise enough to perform a level 24 song at 70.

TM's Knight Who Says Nee was similar.  Not DevCrit but more damage and AC with Divine boost feats.

At any rate, Santa should steer clear of high-level mages who will shred any mantles erected with scrolls quickly and then Bigby and steal his bag of goodies... unless the module uses a lame AI that allows a PC to get within taunt range of them. Like I said, having never played your chosen SP world, it wouldn't be a bad idea to describe the environment focus if you decide to publish it as a finished build.

I don't know if there was ever any resolution here, but, for what it's worth (particularly now, it the absence of an Easter Bunny): Santa has to be Pally - "He's making a list, he's checking it twice, he's gonna find out who's naughty and nice." So we know he's given to arbitrary judgements; and I would think Monk - no weapons or armour on display, and has to be a bit nippy getting around everywhere in one night without being seen. And, much as I want to say Cleric, I think PDK rises its head here - transport and charisma.

I also think Dwarf is right - in the same way as Larrel's daughter (an Elf who's name escapes me) worked with and led the dwarfs in IWD, so the bearded wonder could gain co-operation from his stringy cohorts. Dwarfs give better beards anyway.
